This seems very simple to answer. When corporate media, to
whom lots of people still pay attention, report upon
this medicare story, they do not explain in down to earth
terms what the claims actually mean, and why these claims
are fundamentally groundless and highly manipulative. As a result, when the phrase
used includes "cut medicare by 716billion", the people in the
audience most likely to respond with anxiety will not at the same
time have it explained to them, in equally concrete terms, that this claim is false. When this occurs repeatedly, this only
solidifies the confusion and makes it more difficult to convince the same groups of listeners what is true and what is false.

When you take into account the next few months of superpac
distortions and lies on the same topic, as well as others, it will then not at all be surprising that confusion becomes permanent.

This technique of embedding lies/distortions within media
discourse that can never be confronted as such as soon as they are articulated, and surely never by confronting the original sources of the lie in a context that allows for systematic discussion and extended back and forth with people who understand what the actual story is, has been used over and over again by those who understand how to exert power by
media manipulation via the rhetoric used as well as the forums during which their manipulative discourses are given.

The Universe is not Fair or just. The Universe in fact has a bias against life. Rocks fall from the sky often. Yet the Earth abounds with life. It could be Life in the Universe is as common as dirt. There are planets everywhere and there could be Life everywhere among them. We don't know yet.

If life turns out to be truly rare and we are unique. That fact could speak for the existence of God. If Life is as common as dirt that could still speak for God. Both could speak for their not being a God as well. We don't know and must take either position on Faith.

There is a difference between the Physical Universe and The Life that dwells within it. The Lifeless Universe will never give rise to God if God is not now here. Life on the other hand always has the potential to learn to master the Universe and find or become God.

The quest to find or become God in the process may be the very reason for the existence of life in the first place. Life within the universe could be the fire from which God rises like a Phoenix. If this is true being dead might in fact be the beginning rather than an end in itself. There is no way to know but it might be prudent to live as if this were so.

We moved from the city (860 sq. ft.) to a village (2000 sq. ft) on Lake Huron. We bought an 1891 home and renovated, upgraded and concentrated on main floor living, everything energy efficient. When family visits we have a guest room upstairs.
We concentrated on making our home handicapped accessible for the future.
Our energy costs are down and every room has a view. The proceeds from our city home allowed us to have all these upgrades and keep a nest egg. Every person has a different way of dealing with how they live. As long as it's not ostentatious and an energy hog I think people should be able to feel comfortable with their livestyle.
The McMansions will become the white elephants eventually. The most important
thing is having a home not a house.
I think New York city is a different state of mind.

I have suddenly suffered a peculiar form of anxiety, this being that in next Sunday's Times I will come across another piece like this one.

As I do not doubt for a moment Ms. Tan's O.C.D. history, the article wouldn't normally bother me that much, but since John Cage, arguably the greatest phony in the history of (so-called) serious American composition, is held up by Ms. Tan as being not only a free spirit, but also a logical philosophical descendant of Thoreau, it is not surprising that both his music and his philosophy have helped her, although she may have been predisposed to benefit from Mr. Cage's free-spiritedness and his Thoreauness (sorry, couldn't resist that). She will, of course, know better than I whether this is possible.

But I really do wish that John Cage had followed through on his original intention to give up composing music and undergo psychoanalysis, for while his music may have given Ms. Tan what she needed, Mr. Cage has somewhat simultaneously been responsible for the onset over some sixty years of my own O.C.D., which manifests itself in truly uncontrollable bursts of banging my head against the wall (and, of course, counting each bang) every time I hear Mr. Cage's music or, worse, hear anyone describe what he wrote as actually being music.

In chiding Mr. Romney over his statement that cutting defense would result in job loss, Prof. Krugman is not arguing that this is a false statement. Of course cuts to defense spending would result in job loss. Any cuts in federal or state spending results in job loss. The point is Mr. Romney's hypocrisy. He has campaigned vigorously on the principle that government spending does not create jobs and as proof claims that the stimulus act in 2009 was a failure, in spite of overwhelming evidence to the contrary. Again, Krugman's point was Romney's hypocrisy.

My senator, Orrin Hatch, is likewise a hypocrit on this point. He denounces any attempts by Democrats to create jobs through government spending while campaigning on the promise to increase defense spending in Utah because of its importance in creating private sector jobs. Republicans are all Keynesians when in comes to defense spending, but won't budget another cent to create jobs in education or construction. Thus, the Republican House refuses to vote on President Obama's American Jobs bill.

It should be obvious to us all by now that Romney's coyness is his campaign strategy. As demonstrated by his unreleased tax returns, by his missing policy details, and by a lack of clarity for what he really believes. Never mind the 'why' questions, like 'why would lower taxes on high incomes help the economy?'. He knows not to answer with anything but mind-numbing nostrums.

Romney is like a parent who refuses to explain to a child the reasons for anything except with a perfunctory 'because I say so'. He doesn't want his authority challenged, but, unlike a parent, he has no justification. While that may work with children, Romney proposes to be a public servant, not a public parent. He patronizes every voter with his 360 degree cloak of vagueness.

So to be elected, Romney has decided he must only parrot conservative keywords. Keywords that evoke anger, resentment, and spite. Keywords that drive the basest members of his party to the polls. He need only remain silent as such people attempt to suppress minority voting privileges. He need only remain vague, because he knows members of his party require but the say-so of a conservative authority figure. He need only make sure people believe what they need to believe to vote for him.

Just like Romney's coyness and lack of candor, his campaign strategy reveals his self-absorption. And it is simply put: "Ask not what I can do for my country. Ask what hardships you are willing to let me impose on others."

For the first time in the history of mankind, the so called "assembly line murder" was put to execution in the extermination camps of Auschwitz, Treblinka, Chelmno, Sobibor and in many other parts of eastern Poland where men , women and children were made to stand in the queue, to enter a sealed chamber in which they would be gassed by lethal Zyklon B gas. The bodies of victims were then incinerated en masse in crematoria and open fires. It’s mindboggling to think that in Treblinka, just a handful of staff, of 120, killed some 750,000 to 900,000 Jews during the Camp's 17 months of operation. In 1939 as the World War II began, Albert Camus wrote in his diary 'the reign of beasts has begun'..
Let us not therefore commit blasphemy by trying to perpetuate the memory of a fiend by naming our business institutions after him.

http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/3684288.stm
